head.title: Free Trade: Why Labor Is Wary

hedline.hl1: Free Trade: Why Labor Is Wary

abstract.p: Letter from Flora Waples says flaw in James P Hoffa's argument that jobs will be lost with free trade bill (May 11 Op-Ed) is that unemployment rate in United States is lowest it has been in decades, even after passage of North American Free Trade Agreement

block.p: James P. Hoffa, the teamsters' president, says (Op-Ed, May 11) hundreds of thousands of jobs have been lost since passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement and uses this example to argue against permanent normal trade status for China. The flaw in his argument is that the unemployment rate in this country is the lowest it has been in decades. It is impossible for hundreds of thousands of jobs to have been lost if more people have jobs now than in the past.

James P. Hoffa, the teamsters' president, says (Op-Ed, May 11) hundreds of thousands of jobs have been lost since passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement and uses this example to argue against permanent normal trade status for China. The flaw in his argument is that the unemployment rate in this country is the lowest it has been in decades. It is impossible for hundreds of thousands of jobs to have been lost if more people have jobs now than in the past.

What has, in fact, occurred is that low-paying manufacturing jobs have been moved to foreign countries, while the United States has created a surplus of higher paying, higher skilled jobs. The net effect is not that Americans have lost jobs but that Americans have changed jobs to their economic advantage.
